div.l: And wente vn to the Carpentꝰers walle
He kowhed first and knokked therwith all
Vpon the wyndowe right as he dede er
This Alisou answered who is there
That knokketh so I warant it a thief
Nay nay qd he god wote my swete lyef
I am thyne Absalou I am thy dere derlyng
Of gold qd he I haue the brought a ryng
My moder gaf it me so god me saue
Ful fyne it is and ther to weel y grave
This wole I yeuen the if thow me kysse
This Nicholas was rysen fo for to pysse
And thought he wold amende all the Iape
He shuld kysse his ars er he dede scape
And ope the wyndowe dede he hastely
And out his ars he put preuyly
Ouꝰere the buttok to the haunche bone
And there with spake this Clerk þis Absalou
Speke swete brydde I ne wote where thow arte
This Nicholas a none lete flye a farte
As grete as it had be a thundre dente
That with the strook he was all moost y blente
And he was redy with hise yron hote
And Nicholas in the ars he smote
Of goth the skynne an hand brede a boute
The hote cultre brenned so his toute
And for þe smerte he wened for to deye
As he were wode for woo he gan to crye
Helpe water water helpe for goddes herte
This Carpenter out of his slombre sterte
And herde one crye water as he were wode
And thought allas Noyes Flode
And sette hym with woordes moo
And with an ax smette the corde a twoo
And doun goth all he fonde neyther to selle
Bꝰerred ner ale till he come to the selle
Vpon the floor and theron swowned he lay
Vp sterte hir Alisou and Nicholay
And cryed out me harrowe in the strete
The neybous bothe smale and grete
In ronne for to gawren on this man
That a swowne lay bothe pale and wan
For wtith þat fal he hath y broken his arme
But standen he must vn to his owen harme
For whan he spake he was a none borne doun
With hende Nicholas and Alisoūn
They tolde euꝰery man þat he was wode
He was so a gaste of Noyes Flode
Thurgh fantasye þat of his vanite
He had y bought hym knedynge tubbes three
And had hem hanged in the roof a boven
And þat he parayed hem for goddes love
To sytten in the roof pur companye
The folke gan lawghen at his fantasye
And to the roof they keken and they gape
And torned all his harme into a Iape
For what so euꝰere this Carpentꝰere answerde
It was for nought no man his reson herde
With othes grete he was so sworne a doun
That he was holden wode in all þat toun
For euꝰery Clerk a none right helde with other
They seid this man is wode my lief brother
And euꝰery wight gan laghen at hise stryfe
Thus swyved was þe Carpentꝰers wyfe
For all hise kepyng and his ielosye
And Absalou hath kyssed hir nether eye
And Nicholas is scalded in his toute
This tale is done and god saue all þe route
Here endethh the Tale of the Miller

And now begynneth the prolog͗e of
the Reves Tale
Whan folk han laghen at this nyce caas
Of Absalon and hende Nicholas
Diủers folk diủersely they seide
But for þe more they lough and pleyde
Ne at þis tale I sawgh no man hym greve
But if it were onely Oswalde þe Reve
By cause he was of carpenters crafte
A lytel ire is in his herte lafte
He gan to grutche and blamed it a lyte
So thyk qᵈuod he ful weel coude I yow a quyte
With bleryng of a proude myllers eye
Yf that me luste to speke of Rybaldrye
But I am olde me lust nat pleye for age
Grasse tyme is done my fodre is forrage
This white top writeth myne olde yeres
Myne herte is also mowled as myne here is
But if I fare as doth an open ars
